reviewText: This is the fifth video I've tried from the old FitPrime series.  I've found the FitPrime workouts to be quite quirky, but I think that's what I like about them. In particular, I appreciate the variety of unique moves, particularly those using the tall box/high step combined with basic choreography and providing an overall great workout.  Lately, I've really been enjoying Tracie Long's Fast Cheetah, and I was hoping that Steamin' Cardio would provide another fun, cardio-focused workout.  I'm happy to report that this video is exactly what I had hoped it would be-I love it!The Steamin' Cardio DVD is very well-chaptered as listed below.  I've added my own brief descriptions of each segment as well as approximate times.  The only equipment used for this workout is the tall box and a set of light dumbbells.1. Credits2. Intro3. Warm Up, 3 minutes.  Basic steps and some fun punches provide a good full-body warm up.4. Tree Stretch, 4 minutes.  Includes a few nice hip opening moves.5. Sashay, 3:45 minutes.  A side-to-side sashay combined with repeater knees and kicks.6. Steppy Squats, 2 minutes.  Squats combined with bicep curls and rear leg extensions.7. Press Punch, 2 minutes.  Tall step presses with a punch combination.8. Hippy Curls, 3:40 minutes.  A more dancey segment with lots of swaying hip moves; the choreography was a bit more complicated here, as it included turns/pivots.9. Handstands, 2:40 minutes.  Handstands from a seated on box position-you place your hands on the floor and jump up lifting your hips.  These were combined with tricep dips/jacks and "springs" (sit, hover, jump to stand), making this a tough segment.10. Lunge Row, 2 minutes.  Side lunges plus side leg extensions; also curtsy dips with overhead presses.11. Bootcamp, 3 minutes.  Challenging series of lunges to plank and full push-ups.12. Jab Kick, 3 minutes.  More kickboxing, this time on the floor with a jab-cross/back kick combo.  This was fun, but the order of the moves felt a bit awkward.13. Spider, 3 minutes.  Not sure where the name "spider" comes from; these were sports cardio drills including jumprope, football drills, jumps, and side hops/skates.14. Dip Jumps, 3 minutes.  The last tough cardio segment:  tall box climbs combined with a rear dip/jump combo.15. Mambo Pivots, 3 minutes.  Another more dancey cardio segment, this one includes mambos, pivots, side steps, and hops forward/back to finish the cardio work.16. Bell Crunches, 3 minutes.  A short, effective crunch segment:  lying toe touches holding the weights, single leg lowers, reverse crunches/rolls with weights behind the knees, and oblique knee drops.17. V-Sits, 2:40 minutes.  Teaser variation combined with "goddess" move (on all 4s, open up one leg and arm to the side, then the other) and planks.18. Clams, 2:20 minutes.  This final abs move involves lying on side and pulling knees into the chest; leg stretches are performed on both sides as well.19. V's & T's, 3:20 minutes.  This final stretch segment includes lying hamstring and low back stretches plus additional standing moves.I clocked this workout right around 51 minutes, and according to my heart rate monitor, I was in my target zone for about 30 minutes of this workout-good, and I expect that it will be even better once I get all of the moves down.  I used 5-lb. dumbbells for all of the weight work, but the second time I did the workout, I also added my 1-lb. weighted gloves.  I can't imagine going much higher than this with the weights, but that's fine since I definitely felt the burn!  Also, although the abs work is short, I could feel it a bit in my core the next day.  As mentioned above, I really loved this workout overall, especially the kickboxing moves, the tall box work, and all of the great stretches thrown in.  Steamin' Cardio is a fun, intermediate level workout; I give it 4 and a half stars, and I definitely recommend it!
summary: Exactly what I had hoped it would be!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a pretty good workout dvd. This is my first dvd with Kelsie Daniels and I do like her. At first I was confused by the set and equipment (where's the Fanny Lifter?) and the style of the workout because I had it in my mind that this was a Firm workout, but then I realized, duh it's not. So anyway...I would say this is a fairly challenging workout for anyone in beginner through intermediate levels. Beginners might find it a little too difficult since a lot of the moves depend on a certain amount of strength and ability to do repetitions. It's not high intensity cardio so if you're looking to bounce, step, whatever until you're drenched in sweat and feel like you're going to tip over this isn't going to do it. This is more of a cardio workout through some bouncing and a fair bit of jumping/stepping plyometrics. The moves will challenge you and build strength, some of them are harrrrd, like thigh burning hard, the focus is mostly on lower body, there are some arm moves, but not a lot. The routine is pretty easy to get down, after two workouts I have it mostly, there is a mambo part that's going to take a bit to get...but it's easy enough to just mambo back and forth until you can pick up all of her turns and what not. The section with the jump rope, football drills to jumps etc. is tough, but I really like it and you can tell Kelsie is excited so that helps. She's really good at letting you know what's coming up next and not too bad at queing right and left (I think Stephanie Corley spoiled me), there are couple of spots where she messes up and it kind of throws you off, but once you have the routine down pat I think you'll gloss right over it. They change camera angles ocassionally in weird spots which can be a little disorienting, but I think easy enough to get used to. I will say of all the Firm and other workouts I've ever done this one worked parts of my butt that I didn't even know could be worked, across even the top and middle of my buns were sore the next day, it felt good so yay for that. There's a goddess floor exercise that she does after the abs section (nice little ab section) that is hard and a little awkward, I can't do it so I improvise by getting on knees/hands and extending right leg and left arm out bringing them in etc. Eventually I think I'll be strong enough for the goddess. Overall this is a decent little workout and I'd say good for someone who finds non-cardio lower body strength training too borring (me) and for someone who might need a change between the usually step and bounce routines.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really like Kelsie Daniels Firm workouts. This is similar; a younger Kelsie, a lower production value. It's just her in someone's house (???) doing an ass-kicking workout. I like it, but prefer the Firm series; the poor editing and jumpiness between routines is distracting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video was made before Kelsie Daniels joined the FIRM exercise team.  Kelsie is a very talented workout instructor. Her directions are clear, and she does a great job of coaching you through each exercise.  Kelsie is a task master.  You will work, and you will sweat, but if you stick with Kelsie you will be in better shape.  This is a very effective routine.  You don't waste a second of time. I don't regret one single minute I spend with Kelsie!
summary: Kelsie Daniels will whip you into shape
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can't improve upon the other review listed here, but I did want to put my two cents in.  The original Steamin' Cardio doesn't have the higher production value of the newer release with Heidi Tanner, but it's still a great workout.  I don't know if I'll ever master the pseudo-handstand move, but it's always fun to attempt it. Kelsie is so incredibly fit; she's very inspiring. I'm so glad she was included in the new Firm DVD releases, including "Tight Buns & Killer Legs" where she's the instructor!
summary: Low production value, high quality workout!
Title: N/A
